title: xercise for the lazy
intro: What is the least amount of exercise someone can get away with doing whilst still staying healthy? Sam and Neil talk about it and teach you related vocabulary.
this_week_question: According to new UK government advice, what is the minimum number of steps we should walk every day to stay healthy?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: a promise that you make to yourself to improve your lifestyle by starting to do something good for you (or stop doing something bad) in the coming year
increase the amount of effort you put into whatever activity you are doing; try harder
a situation where you accept the disadvantages of something in order to get the benefits it brings
involving little exercise or physical activity
a task that is both easy to accomplish and brings positive results
a better result for the same amount of effort you put into something

transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And I’m Sam. Did you make any New Year’s resolutions this year, Neil? They’re  promises that you make to yourself to do something positive in the coming year… And now that we’re into February, it’s getting harder to keep those promises!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, the same promises I make every year, Sam – to exercise more and get fit. But I’m too lazy to go running on cold winter mornings - I’d rather stay in bed!

transcript.author: Sam

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Of course, any exercise is better than none. ‘Structured exercise’ - activities like going to a fitness class, or swimming are great. But if that’s not possible, we’ll be hearing about small changes you can make that will help as well.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Which is good news because fewer and fewer of us of doing what the UK government recommends - thirty minutes of moderate exercise a day. So, Sam, according to new government advice, what is the minimum number of steps we should walk every day to stay healthy? Is it:

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: I’ll say a) five thousand steps per day.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, Sam. We’ll find out the answer at the end of the programme. Someone else who’s interested in how little exercise he can do is BBC reporter, James Gallagher. Here’s James speaking with sports physiologist, Dr Zoe Saynor, after Zoe had been monitoring James’s fitness while running on a treadmill for BBC Radio 4 programme, Inside Science.

transcript.author: Dr Zoe Saynor
transcript.text: … I also know you do regularly try and do structured exercise.

transcript.author: James Gallagher
transcript.text: Just to be clear, my structured exercise training is going for a swim once a week.

transcript.author: Zoe
transcript.text: Generally, that's fantastic! I guess my question to you would be, how hard do you push yourself when you go swimming?

transcript.author: James
transcript.text: Not as hard as the treadmill.

transcript.author: Zoe
transcript.text: I think the big thing if we come back to this question of what is the least I can do? There's clear evidence that if you want to do shorter exercise sessions, they need to be of a higher intensity, right?

transcript.author: James
transcript.text: So there's a trade-off.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Zoe says that if you don’t have much time to exercise it’s okay to do shorter sessions, as long as you push yourself – try harder and put more effort into what you’re doing. If you can swim a length in forty seconds, push yourself to swim it in thirty-five.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That means exercising harder of course, but for a shorter time. In other words, there’s a trade-off – you accept the disadvantages of something in order to get the benefit it brings.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Another problem for many people is that their job is sedentary – it involves little exercise or physical activity. Zoe thinks it’s important that office workers who sit down all day also find time to exercise. Here she shares her tips with BBC Radio 4 programme, Inside Health.

transcript.author: Dr Zoe Saynor
transcript.text: Especially people who have office jobs are sat down all day, we then look at some of the easy wins . So, active travel, and even if that's parking a little bit further away. transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Zoe’s suggestions for active travel, things like walking from the car, and using the stairs instead of the lift, are easy wins - tasks that are both easy to accomplish and bring benefits.

transcript.author: Sam
